results.title: Making coins
results.brief_description: This film is a description of the making of coins in the Royal Mint today, with a brief historical introduction touching on some early British coins. Follows with a detailed tour through the departments of the Royal Mint from the melting house to the final inspection and despatch of the finished coins.

results.title: Making Chunky Move: C.O.R.R.U.P.T.E.D. 2
results.creator_credit: Peter Hennessey, Angharad Wynne-Jones, Erin Brannigan and PAML
results.brief_description: Making Chunky Move C.O.R.R.U.P.T.E.D. 2. is an exploration of how Chunky Move, one of Australia’s most exciting contemporary dance companies created this new dance work. It follows the company from the germ of an idea, to the stage, behind the scenes and beyond, with snapshot interviews with the key players, dancers, creative collaborators and other cultural identities as well as unique virtual 3D segments, sound bites and extensive footage.

results.title: Making books
results.brief_description: The story of the mass production of books in the USA, showing the ingenuity and technology used at the Country Life Press, Garden City, New York. The film follows every process from the author’s manuscript to the finished book on the bookstall stand.

results.title: Making biscuit
results.brief_description: Making Biscuit shows life in a biscuit factory through the eyes and experiences of women employed in the blue collar industry. Four ex-employees of a biscuit making company were directly involved in making this film which was animated from over 2,000 slides.

results.title: Making baskets: an art adventure
results.creator_credit: Easy Street Productions and Bill Mackie
results.brief_description: Shows a young woman and three elmentary grade students making baskets from a variety of materials including leaves, pine needles, rope and yarn. Demonstrates in detail each step of cording, wrapping, coiling and stitching. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Making babies
results.creator_credit: Gwynne Basen, Mary Armstrong, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation, National Film Board of Canada and Cinefort
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “On the eighth day: perfecting Mother Nature”.
From a high tech marketplace in Paris, to the work being done at a fertility clinic in London, Ontario and a surrogacy centre in Los Angeles, “Making babies” takes a critical look at reproductive technology. Through interviews with doctors, drug salesmen, infertile women, surrogates and feminist critics like Gena Corea, the film explores the origins and application of the technology and the dangers it may pose to women and to society as a whole.

results.title: Making a wira
results.creator_credit: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones, Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “People of the Australian western desert (A)”.
Djunjurai locates a suitable tree from which to make a small wooden digging dish or wira. He starts on the tree trunk by using the hand chopper he had made, but after a time changes to a metal axe. The raw material for the dish is brought back to camp where he shapes it with an adze.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ian Dunlop, John Martin-Jones, Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies and Australian Commonwealth Film Unit

results.title: Making a stone axe
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Alcheringa (A)”.
Shows how Australia’s Aborigine lived hundreds of years ago. Primitive methos of tool making require both skill and patience. By means of grinding stones, the stone axe is shaped to the desired form.
